title: Will the UK or EU trigger Article 16 of the Northern Ireland Protocol before 1 February 2022?
preds: Unlikely in the next few days
The UK government is too distracted by Boris Johnson's fate to deal with difficult political issues, and Liz truss is still reading into her brief
Adjusting prediction down as we get closer to the end of the month
Everyone only has one or two other things in their minds, Russia, Covid parties, eu presidencies, national elections, China.  Hmmm does anything else need to be added?

Only slightly more than a week to go, ending on a Monday (31 January). Why would any side trigger Article 16 now if all possible root causes, the Northern Ireland border issue in particular, have been known for about 150 times that time span (i.e. about three years) at least?
Re-read question, did some deeper research, and updated accordingly.  There seems little reason (or interest) for any party to trigger article 16 by 1 Feb 2022.

What would necessitate a use of Article 16 clause?  "Serious economic, societal or environmental difficulties that are liable to persist, or to diversion of trade". Do these difficulties exist and are they serious? Unknown who is defining 'serious', but they do exist but are more attributed to COVID and supply chain difficulties being felt globally. 
What is the protocol for invoking? 1) Unable to agree to a joint approach, and 2) a month formal notice is (supposedly) required before action is taken. 
January 14, 2022 The Guardian reports, "Liz Truss said there was “a deal to be done” over the post-Brexit arrangements for Northern Ireland after “constructive talks” with her EU counterpart raised hopes of less rancorous relations with Brussels."
https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/jan/14/brexit-deal-northern-ireland-liz-truss-talks-eu As many before have said, I do not find it credible that the UK or EU will want to disrupt the sensitive Brexit negotiations and agreements through unilateral action at this point. Extremely low probability that IF that does happen, that it will happen prior to February 1, 2022 - given another week of negotiations.
Article 16 will not be triggered before 2/1/2022
After further update it appears even less likely at this time
Seems like a last resort and ultimately will degrade economic activity for most parties involved.
Time is running out, and if it happens it is very unlikely to happen before the 1st of February.
With elections upcoming and an already sensative Brexit deal in place, it's unlikely anyone will want to jeopardize the situation.
Currently, it seems like Article 16 doesn't specify definitions such as "serious" difficulty. Additionally, it's unlikely actors want to complicate the already sensitive Brexit deal.

Negotiations are just now starting in mid-January.  I think they will give it a little more time.  Also, there aren't elections until May of this year, so that takes a little bit of time pressure off; not much, but some.  https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-58790419

The UK wants to denude the present arrangement by removing most border checks.  The EU has the right to retaliate, but the likely level of retaliation at this stage is quite low.  Taking action would take time.  Therefore, the UK doesn’t have much to fear from taking aggressive action.  On the other hand, the EU might just give in to negotiations.
Liz Truss not yet up to speed on the subject. Talks will only start between her and Sefcovic this week. Too soon to tack drastic steps.
OK. I will raise my forecast given the negotiations are still going with Frosts replacement.  She threatens and shouts as much as he did.
https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/jan/09/liz-truss-willing-to-trigger-article-16-of-brexit-protocol-if-talks-falter Let the finger-pointing begin for the apparently inevitable.
Three weeks left, not much news

There's some talk of Liz Truss invoking Article 16 to get some attention as she attempts to become PM but I don't see this happening anytime before February 1. She's new to the job. The goodwill she may get would be off the back of her negotiating trade deals (however poor they are) as Secretary of State for International Trade would be tarnished if she yolo triggers article 16 less than two months in her current job, right as there are negative headlines about costs of Brexit in 2022. If she wants to become PM she also needs to look electable to the tory voters that are currently abstaining/voting lib dem in by-elections and I don't think being rash would help her case when she can instead wait it out for now by setting a later target date to resolve things.
I also can't imagine the EU triggering article 16 in January as Maros Sefcovic said that he wants to be pragmatic and have a clear date to resolve issues, with January being an important month - not the words of someone about to trigger Article 16.

Is triggering Article 16 a solution?
Article 16 of the Northern Ireland Protocol allows both the UK and the EU to unilaterally take action should its application give rise to "serious economic, societal or environmental difficulties that are liable to persist, or to diversion of trade." The provision was designed to be used as a last resort when previous attempts to find a negotiated solution had failed. Both sides have threatened to use the legal weapon on various occasions. In February, Brussels said it was invoking Article 16 amid a row over COVID-19 vaccine imports. The European Commission feared Northern Ireland could be used as a backdoor to avoid export control and bring EU-made vaccines into British territory. But the EU was forced to backpedal after the move sparked international outrage.

=

No triggering of protocol, more new négociation to fine tune the deal

As part of Brexit, negotiations were made to avoid a solid border between Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland (maintaining Good Friday treaty 1998).  However NI is part of UK, RI part of EU.  Article 16 basically sees a much stricter border come into place between NI and RI. External View - Brexit signed Jan 24, 2020.  Almost triggered in Jan 2021 but it was withdrawn immediately.  Calling that a 1/2 occurance, where EU had good reason but withdrew due to medical nature of Covid.
0.5 occurrences in 19 months = 2.6% chance per month.  5.2 months remaining (as of Aug22/2021) = 13.6% base rate on external view. Before triggering there should ideally be negotiations between the parties to try and resolve the dispute.  A lot of other swirling factors make the situation unpredictable and hard to move off external view.
If BoJo feels the need to keep this bit of his base excited, this could happen.  Since it's BoJo, we won't know until the does it.

On January 29th 2021 the EU invoked Article 16 of the Northern Ireland protocol over concerns as the exports of Covid-19 vaccine. After complaints from the all the relevant parties, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen backtracked on the same day, labelling the move as a mistake misjudgement blunder or mishap.
So, the answer is that this event has happened (for one day).
However, assuming the intention of the question is for the triggering to last more than one day, I will suggest the following:
Article 16 does allow for unilateral action if there is ‘serious economic, societal or environmental difficulties that are liable to persist, or to diversion of trade.’
The Union and the UK shall use ‘their best endeavours, in good faith and in full respect of their respective legal orders’ which I suggest is deliberately vague.
The UK has threatened to pull out of the protocol over difficulties for the movement of chilled meats, medicines, pets and plants, among others. The EU have stated that cannot be renegotiation of the protocol. This suggests that a stalemate is in the offing with sabres being rattled.
There are perhaps other issues at play here due to Brexit and the Belfast peace agreement. The protocol which is a result of Brexit created a border in the Irish Sea that has developed into political eruptions coming into play in N.I. The Conservative government cannot be seen to help break up the Union of the UK and can (will) not allow for arbitration with the European Court of Justice which would defeat the object of leaving the EU. The Eu has insisted on the full complement of customs inspections that are not used in other border jurisdictions suggesting a degree of intransigence and perhaps an attempt to split NI from the UK.
Any negotiations with the EU tend to go to the wire. Perhaps realpolitik and pragmatism to forgo a threat to trade will prevail.
Merkel is stepping down and Macron’s popularity is slumping with Presidential elections in April 2022, the chief antagonists against renegotiation of the protocol will be gone.

Back in June Lord Frost announced the UK would not be triggering Article 16 of the protocol - which would allow it to suspend parts of the Brexit deal - before talks with Brussels He added that the government believed using it was justifiable, but said: "Nevertheless, we have concluded that it is not the right moment to do so."

Information about article 16: https://ukandeu.ac.uk/explainers/article-16-of-the-northern-ireland-protocol/ Tough forecast to make. I would think it is not likely that it would be trigerred because the whole purpose of Article 16 is to move a topic to the committee so they can talk about it. But the committee does nothing but talk about things. So really there is no need to actually start the article 16 process except to make a political communication to your domestic supporter but the same communication can be made to your domestic supporters without causing consternation with the negotiating partner by simlly threatening to invoke article 16.  There will be lots of words and bluffery but in the end they will negotiate the wrinkles out like civilized nations.
